newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Two rare Nepalese red pandas born in NZ zoo.
newsitem.headline: Two rare Nepalese red pandas born in NZ zoo.

text.p: Tashi, a Nepalese red panda at Auckland zoo in New Zealand, gave birth to two cubs on Monday in a New Year boost for the endangered species.
Zoo spokeswoman Frances Valintine said the new arrivals were grey, about three inches (seven cm) long and resembled small rodents.
The worldwide population of Nepalese red pandas is about 300, of which 222 are in captivity. "Through deforestation, there's no habitat left for them," Valintine said.
The births were part of a captive breeding programme designed ultimately to return some animals to the wild, with plans to create a national park in their native Nepal, she said.
The animals are not directly related to the giant panda and bear some resemblance to a raccoon, with rusty fur, white stripes and rings around the eyes, said Valintine.
Zoo staff were able to see the cubs via an infra-red camera in a nesting box, but cannot yet determine their sex.

The cubs were suckling while mother Tashi rested and father Mario displayed total indifference. "At the moment he's showing no interest. He plays a very low key role as far as parenting," Valintine said.
